doc.title: NOAURA
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Nomura/First Insights - Euro area Inflation still at targetFirst Insights - Euro area Inflation still at target_2025-08-29

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Nomura
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Nomura

passages.text: - We forecast euro area HICP inflation for August (released 2 September) to print unchanged at \(2.0\%\) y-o-y. This would be the third month HICP inflation printed in line with the ECB's target, suggesting some stabilisation in euro area HICP inflation.
- We continue to see no further cuts from the ECB, with its depo rate unchanged at \(2.00\%\) for the foreseeable future.

We believe euro area HICP inflation, released 2 September, is likely to be in- line with the ECB's target of \(2.0\%\) . We track euro area HICP inflation at \(2.04\%\) . This is based on almost \(81\%\) of country- level data released thus far. Beyond August, we expect HICP inflation to hover around the ECB's \(2.0\%\) target until year- end. We track euro area core HICP inflation at \(2.21\%\) .
Country- level data so far suggest services price momentum and core goods price momentum in August 2025 were broadly in line with typical price momentum for an August prior to the pandemic.
Fig.1:Nomura's euro area inflation cheat sheet

28 AugustNomuraConsensusOutturnTimeCountryIndicatorJulAugAugAug10:30BelgiumHICP2.61--2.629 AugustNomuraConsensusOutturnTimeCountryIndicatorJulAugAugAug07:45FranceHICP0.940.800.90.808:00SpainHICP2.702.782.82.709:30SloveniaHICP2.93--3.010:00ItalyHICP1.721.661.81.711:00PortugalHICP2.50--2.513:00Germany*HICP1.772.142.02.11 SeptemberNomuraConsensusOutturnTimeCountryIndicatorJulAugAugAug11:00IrelandHICP1.58---2 SeptemberNomuraConsensusOutturnTimeCountryIndicatorJulAugAugAug05:30NetherlandsHICP2.50---08:00AustriaHICP3.67---10:00Euro areaHICP2.031.992.1-10:00Euro areaCore HICP2.312.172.2-10:00Euro areaServices HICP3.323.083.1-
Source: Bloomberg, Macrobond, Nomura

- Germany: German HICP inflation for August ticked up to \(2.1\%\) y-o-y from \(1.8\%\) in July. This was in line with our-above consensus forecast prior to today's regional CPI data. It means the CPI-HICP wedge for August 2025 was 14bp lower than the August 2024 wedge. Services price momentum remains elevated relative to a typical August. Core goods price momentum, meanwhile, was weaker than is typical for an August, albeit core goods price momentum has been weaker than was typical pre-pandemic for much of this year.
- France: French HICP inflation for August fell to \(0.8\%\) y-o-y from \(0.9\%\) in July, in line with Nomura's below-consensus forecast. Within the CPI details, services price

momentum slowed, and the monthly pace of services inflation printed in line with the August average in 2010- 19. Core goods prices momentum also slowed, and now stands broadly in line with its pre- pandemic average.

- Italy: Italian HICP inflation for August was unchanged at \(1.7\%\) y-o-y, in line with Nomura's below-consensus forecast.- Spain: Spanish HICP inflation for August was unchanged at \(2.7\%\) y-o-y, which is 10bp weaker than we and the consensus had forecast. The press release suggested upward inflationary pressures from fuel prices but downward inflationary pressures from food and electricity. Core CPI rose by 10bp to \(2.4\%\) y-o-y. It is important to caveat the definition of core CPI in Spain, however, includes processed food. In terms of underlying momentum, it is only 10bp above its pre-pandemic average, suggesting a monthly pace of core inflation that is almost in line with its pre-pandemic pace.

The ECB is well- placed to navigate upcoming US trade policy uncertainty, according to Mme Lagarde, as the depo rate at \(2.00\%\) is in the middle of the ECB's neutral range (1.75- \(2.25\%\) ). At the July meeting, Mme Lagarde suggested data misses or economic events would have to lower the ECB's 2027 HICP inflation forecast to alter the rate path.

Although Q2 2025 GDP growth was weaker than the ECB's forecast by 10bp, we believe Q3 2025 GDP growth will be stronger than the ECB's forecast by 30bp. Additionally, we believe euro area HICP inflation is likely to average \(2.0\%\) in H2 2025. As a result, we see no further cuts from the ECB. We expect the ECB to leave its depo rate unchanged at \(2.00\%\) for the foreseeable future.
